p: Some monoterpenoids exhibit significant toxicity to bacteria by interfering with bacterial cell membranes. Besides, the accumulation of terpenoids precursors (such as IPP) has a negative impact on bacterial growth ( Paramasivan and Muttur, 2017). Production of monoterpenoids often needs to express cytochrome P450 genes, which is not easy to achieve in bacteria. In view of these, S. cerevisiae is becoming an attractive host for monoterpenoid bio-production, due to its robustness, well-studied genetic background, applicability to industrial bioprocesses, and the possibility for terpene scaffold decoration by the functional expression of cytochrome P450 enzymes ( Zhang et al., 2008). In particular, S. cerevisiae is classified as generally regarded as safe (GRAS) by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) ( Nevoigt, 2008). However, compared with plant cells, S. cerevisiae lacks monoterpene synthetase, so it has no ability to synthesize monoterpenoids directly.
